title: Quality of Code
body:
The code written to perform the analysis should be quality assured. There is guidance on Quality Assurance of Code for Analysis and Research produced by the Government Statistical Service and the Analysis Function, which can act as a useful resource for the analysts producing the code. The Principles page contains a useful overview for anyone involved in the running of an analytical project and talks through the three founding principles of good analysis:

  • Reproducible - Other analysts should be able to replicate the work performed; if they run the same analysis, on the same data, they should obtain the same results. Transparency here underpins the above two principles, and supports the requirements of the Code of Practice for Statistics. 
  • Auditable - The reasons behind the analysis should be known, any decisions made should be based on evidence and recorded to safeguard during future scrutiny.  
  • Assured - Often through peer review, the analytical choices made should be understood and reasonable. Quality Assurance should be proportional - analysts shouldn't be overburdened with procedure when unnecessary - and guidance on this is often taken from the Aqua Book.

title: Overview
body:
Before analysis can begin, some thought is needed around what the desired results are. 

Key considerations include:

  • What results are you looking for?
  • What data is needed to perform the analysis?
  • Are there any ethical concerns that need to be considered.  

These correspond with the first two parts of the Analysis Lifecycle from the Government Functional Standard for Analysis, Scoping the analysis, and Designing the analysis. The lifecycle is designed to be an iterative process, with plenty of room for refinement, and returning to earlier steps when new information comes to light.

title: Scoping the Analysis
body:
Scoping the analysis ensures that the question to be answered is defined to a level where analysis can proceed. 

As part of this process, a number of tasks should be completed in collaboration with analysts who will be undertaking the work: 

  • Recording the purpose of the analysis
  • Defining the levels of quality and certainty that are needed
  • Explore requirements and scope with stakeholders

Clear definitions at this stage of the expectations of the work will simplify the rest of the process. Refinement may be needed as later stages of the analytical process progress.

title: Designing the Analysis
body:
The design stage is essential to ensure that the work to be undertaken is suitable for the question being considered. 

The analysis should:

  • be able to answer the question
  • be proportionate to the question being asked,
  • represent good value for money.

Both analysts and subject matter experts should be engaged during this stage to structure the problem clearly, and agree objectives, resources, skills, and a timeline as much as is possible. The analytical lifecycle allows for iteration and refinement, so the initial design should not be considered to be fixed, rather it should adjust to fit changing requirements. 

Some key requirements of all analytical work that should be considered during the design stage are that the work is:

  • repeatable - if a different analyst performs the analysis with the same inputs, the same results should be produced,
  • independent of bias - data should be considered carefully to avoid collection bias, and the analysts personal bias should not play a part in the results,
  • relevant to the question - the analysis performed should be within the scope of the task at hand,
  • objective - the analysis performed and the results presented should be factual and impartial, they should not be influenced by personal opinion, 
  • robust enough to survive challenges - both from other analysts within the civil service, and members of the public who might view the analysis

During the scoping stage of an analysis project, levels of quality and certainty that are required were defined. While this is in reference to the overall quality of the statistics being published, there are other areas where quality must be observed.

title: Quality of Data
body: While the quality of code is essential for analysts, so is the quality of data. Given that our analysis is always data-driven, issues with the data can cause problems throughout the entire analytical lifecycle of a project. There is an Introduction to Data Quality provided by the Government Data Quality Hub which is accessible to all members of the Civil Service, and covers the Data Quality Framework, and explains principles that should be applied to all government data.
